I was in Wendy's the other day with my grandchildren and a group of guys 
sat down a table away from us.  These were not 'rough' looking guys.  Just 
regular working guys out for lunch.  They started a conversation about bow 
ties.  One dude makes a comment to the effect of 'some jackhole in a bow 
tie said you have to tie it yourself'.  My 6 year old grandson looks over 
at me with eyes wide and begins to open his mouth.  I stopped him and just 
told him to eat his lunch.  After a few 'But Gigi, he said....' and points 
in that direction, I got him to go back to his food.  After the meal was 
over my husband took the kids to the car and as I slide out of the booth I 
pulled up a picture on my phone and walked over to the guys.  Smiling 
proudly I showed them the picture of my 6 year old grandson from the 
previous Sunday wearing his brand new bow tie and said to them 'See dudes 
of all ages can wear bow ties.  Isn't he handsome?'  To which they all 
agreed.  Still smiling, I said 'and it's hand tied by me!'   'I can see 
that.  It looks great.' smiled the guy that made the offensive comment.  At 
this point you can tell that these guys are thinking that I'm just a proud 
grandma/mom showing my kid off but then I say, still smiling, 'Sorry to 
interrupt but sitting so close we could hear you conversation and I wanted 
to show my little man off.  You know when you started talking about the bow 
ties, it's funny (insert wry laugh) but my grandson leaned over to me and 
said 'Gigi, I don't know what a jackhole is but my bowtie looked awesome on 
me.'  I think we all agree on that one don't we guys?'  I continued to 
smile as I stepped the few feet away, put my cup in the garbage and said to 
them 'Y'all just might want to remember how close your sitting to kids when 
having any conversation.  Enjoy the rest of your day.' and I left.  Their 
smiles were now gone.  Their mouths were now agape.  The laughter had left 
the table.  

In no way did I censor what they said. I just reminded them that their 
language could have an impact on those around them.  Before anyone says 
anything, yes I know that 'jackhole' is not a majorly 'offensive' word but 
that's not the point.  He could have even said 'some stupid guy in a bow 
tie' and it would have had the same impact.  THAT is my point.  I'm just as 
guilty as the next person to sub things for 'curse' words.  Instead of the 
f-bomb, I will say 'fudge buckets' or 'flippin'.  Instead of s@#t I'll use 
'Jiminy Crickets' or 'poop' even.  (If I use 'poop' or 'crap' then I get 
into trouble for using 'potty words' by the kids though)  I'm not perfect. 
 I have to be reminded too.  

The problem we are facing in this country.... just in this time really... 
is that people are more concerned about their 'freedom' or their 'rights' 
and not thinking about what is *right*.  I watch movie these days and think 
'I can write this.  All it is is the f-bomb every other word, some t&a and 
a couple of explosions.'  It's all shock value. It's ridiculous. Just 
because you *can* doesn't mean you *should*.
Yeah, it's not so much illegal as it is immoral.

The truth is, in reality, there is swearing.  There are "bosoms, blood & 
bad words".  These are part of who were are as people.  By censoring these 
things, are we really protecting people?  Are we truly doing good?  Nudity, 
I am sorry to inform, generally walks hand in hand with the creation of 
life.  Swear words, curses and saying terrible things will all be 
experienced by individuals in their lives.  Sadly, there will be times when 
people will be exposed to violence.  Obscenities are part of the human 
condition.  Is it truly healthy to attempt to completely block out things 
that are fundamentally human?  Is it not better to let our children 
experience these things first in an environment that is not real?  Does it 
not truly protect and prepare our children for things that they will 
ultimately experience why first exposing it to them in a way that can be 
sanitised and can be controlled, in a way that discussion and mutual 
understanding and learning can be present?  I understand a parents need to 
protect their children and to keep them from harm.  I think, in this case, 
protection is not prevention, but rather preparation.  Furthermore, the 
stigmatisation and demonisation of nudity and sexuality is not healthy for 
an individual.  Casting what is arguably the most fundamental aspect of 
humanity as "bad" and as something that requires censorship not only does 
not aid our children, but rather instils them guilt and stigma.  I just 
don't think this is healthy.  I understand the notions that this video is 
trying to convey.  I understand the want and the need for parents to 
protect their children, but I think this video is doing the opposite.﻿

+Jock Murphy "but it doesn't compare to the amount of swearing the average 
person might have done during the same period"

there is absolutely 0 statistical data on this, it'd be purely 
hypothetical. The swearing in movies is based on actual data and is 
therefore relevant. It's an ad, its marketed towards a specific demo and 
that's that.

I personally have no problem with anyone using a service like VidAngel. 
 What I do object to is the fact that this ad (as awesome as it is) is 
asserting a claim based on inference and not facts.  The chart is dramatic, 
but it doesn't compare to the amount of swearing the average person might 
have done during the same period.  It is selling the assumption that 
exposure to "bad things" promotes them; without any proof.

A much better message would have been "If you don't want to 
hear/see/whatever it, we have an option"  They could have even done the 
same visuals but with a much better and more nuanced message; but they 
didn't do that.

+amanda2324
"Intelligent" "Civilized"

More words that carry very subjective definitions. The idea of what is or 
isn't "intelligent" or "civilized" changes dramatically from place to place 
and over time. The definitions of "intelligent" and "civilized" are hardly 
constants in this world.

Were you as educated or as skilled a writer as you imply you would not only 
know this, you would have foreseen this argument and prepared for it.

Stephen King is pretty expressive and he uses swear words correctly placed 
to elicit all sorts of emotions.

Sometimes, you need to speak respectfully in discourse. Sometimes, you need 
to raise your voice to get your point across.
But every once in a while, the only thing that does the trick is a verbal 
kick to the face.

+amanda2324 By that argument, you're saying that every character must speak 
like an eloquent and educated person... but characters are allowed to be 
ineloquent and uneducated. They're supposed to each have their own voices-- 
the voices that come naturally to them. Voices that are different from the 
surrounding narrative. They express things differently. Some might be 
eloquent, but if all the characters sound the same as each other or sound 
like writing rather than speaking then that is bad writing. Sure, dialogue 
is generally a polished version of actual speaking-- you cut out the 
placeholders, and the ums and the ers and the boring pleasantries people 
exchange-- but it still needs to sound like a person. I'm not saying, 
"Therefore you must swear every single sentence because that's what people 
do!" but some people will swear when emotional and that's more true to the 
character than giving them a long eloquent insult that they wouldn't think 
of in that moment. Distinct characters with distinct voices acting like 
people is a part of good writing. Ineloquent characters who sound 
uneducated is not a bad thing. When that happens to include swearing, then 
that's the writer's judgement and sure you can decide not to read it for 
that but calling it automatically bad writing is just deluding yourself. 

In your comment directed to snowboardcincy you complain that his wording 
made him sound more stupid and uneducated, but consider that in writing 
characters, sometimes that's the entire point. And, furthermore, the swear 
word may have less literal meaning but it holds more emotional meaning 
coming from the person who said it. And a normally eloquent person being 
reduced to spouting swears will say something about who they are and how 
they feel in that moment. It does say something about the person-- the 
characters-- saying them. The thing is, that's entirely the point!

snippet.authorDisplayName: My last display name was too long
snippet.textDisplay:
+amanda2324 All the words convey meaning as long as they're not complete 
gibberish.  If it had no meaning than none of us would have been able to 
understand that it's an insult.  Even gibberish can be given meaning with 
the proper tone and context.

You also either missed or dodged the point.  You shouldn't be using swear 
words in your writing unless you want to use them to convey emotion.  They 
shouldn't be included in a documentary about butterflies, it's not the 
right sort of place to drop an f-bomb.  If you want to paint a picture of a 
gritty gun-slinger going through his own personal hell, the right words are 
priceless when not over-used.

+snowboardcincy Or we could ask: which one makes you sound more stupid and 
uneducated, or which one is more appropriate for intelligent, civilized 
discourse, rather than you just throwing a fit because you didn't like 
something? Your second one contains no meaning, and reflects poorly on you 
as a person. The first one gives a better reflection and is better for 
intelligent, civilized discussions, because the words actually mean 
something.

+MegaKaitouKID1412 Your point of the "average person doesn't do this" is 
not a good argument, for the "average person" doesn't do or say a lot of 
the things that occurs in most books and genre's. The whole appeal of many 
genre's is that they /aren't/ like the life or lifestyles of the "average 
person."
+MegaKaitouKID1412 you're the man

+amanda2324  I happen to be a writer, one who makes a living doing it, so I 
consider myself radically good at what I do. Swearing is like anything else 
- there's an appropriate time for it, and there is not. I could say, for 
example, that I thought your comment banal, cursory, and overall, a pseudo 
do-gooder platitude of the most boring variety. Or I could say, I thought 
your comment was a bunch of horse shit. Which communicates the sentiment 
more clearly and efficiently?

+amanda2324 It really just depends on the colloquialism of the character at 
hand. Being a "writer" also means understand the use of language that is 
not necessarily "proper" or "correct" in order to convey narrative thought, 
and sometimes, that's just the tool that's needed for the job.

By example, a curse word can be conveyed as a "cop out," per your 
definition, but it certainly conveys a certain emotion when used properly.

These are words which can convey an entire emotional feeling, an entire 
thought and state of mind in a single utterance. The problem with much of 
current "Hollywood" mindset, however, is that the use of such language is 
so oversaturated throughout a film that the words lose their emotional 
weight.

The use of such language is, and should be, a specific tool in the writer's 
toolbox. But just as one would not utilize a crowbar to hammer, nor it's 
prybar to tighten a screw, so a writer shouldn't apply such language so 
liberally, UNLESS it's the writer's intention to literatically rip up some 
floorboards.

At the end of the day, that's exactly the writer's prerogative, just as 
it's the viewer's to watch or not. We can critique and admonish others to 
follow our personal tastes, but we can't reasonably expect that others will 
follow our "intellectual" literary priorities.

+amanda2324 Actually, believe it or not, I am a writer, and that's why I 
say this. Of course, I do discourage using large amounts of swear words 
because it diminishes the impact when they are spoken and there are other 
options to take. But, again, what would the Princess Bride be without "I 
want my father back you son of a bitch", or Gone with the Wind without 
"Frankly, my dear, I don't give a damn"?

A couple swears where they actually mean something can be extremely 
effective. Sure there are other "proper" words to use rather than swearing, 
but this comes in two flavours: the proper words are less effective than a 
well-chosen swear word, and the fact that average people don't speak in 
flowery or mechanical language to express and emotion, so a well-placed 
swear in dialogue is more true to characters as people.

Because swear words are less intelligent. They are cop outs of other more 
creative and proper ways to express oneself.

I assume you're not a writer, and thus don't understand the idea of there 
being more than one way to get emotions and meaning across to a reader. 
There are plenty. Resorting to swear words is too easy and simple. It takes 
much more thinking and intellect to come up with ways to express one's 
emotions that don't involve swear words.

+jacobjedi2 It used to be public television stations in the United States 
had very strict rules for the use of profanity from 6:00 AM - 10:00 PM (aka 
"children's hours"). These laws weren't just applied to PBS stations, but 
to the stations that you could view without purchasing (non-cable 
stations). In recent years there has been movements to change the laws, 
including allowing frontal nudity during "children's hours." This law 
change was struck down not in the courts, but by a public outcry. There are 
also laws that prohibit the display of extreme graphic content on 
television, especially during "children's hours." This is why the news was 
traditionally set for 10:00 PM, after "after children's hours." 
My point is, we do still have some level of censorship in the United 
States. It is not as stringent as Russia's, but it is a lot stronger than 
what you find in Europe. I'm grateful for some censorship, like no nudity 
on broadcast television/billboards and no f-bomb's during "children's 
hours."

someone does this, with their family, and then some day their children step 
into the bigger world and are bombarded with the natural occurrence of 
profanity. Imagine the shock, if the worst expletive they've ever heard is 
'heck'! It's a way of channeling emotion without acting physically upon 
impulse. A critical part of language - not to be censored. Swearing is not 
a 'base' form of language in any sense, being one of the more advanced 
processes humans use to express their feelings. 
What's worse, the advocates for this are generalizing all types of 
swearing. Calling someone a 'shit' is, of course, abusive, but if you stub 
your toe, for example, its meaning changes.
Such a line of thought is the same reason why nowadays you cannot so much 
as step over a wooden plank without first completing a risk assesment, 
emergency procedure training, and submitting a thesis on the safety 
parameters of wood.... ﻿

+Slider1207 Anecdotal evidence of this was given by a friend of mine who is 
a prison guard. Based on his assessment of hundreds of inmates and their 
language habits, as a segment of society, their use of profanity is much 
more frequent than that of the rest of society. I'm sorry I couldn't give 
you a more formal study on the correlation of violent behaviors and 
profanity, but it is some evidence nevertheless.

There have been other studies done on the use of profanity during therapy 
sessions and the training for therapists is that they should not react to 
the use of profanity by those they are administering therapy rather the 
physician should " ...treat it as another symptom of the patients’ 
interpersonal difficulties..." (This quote was found in the abstract to 
"Toward the Therapeutic Use of Obscene Language: A Legal and Clinical 
Review" by Mejor MD, and Miller MD PhD.) Among other things this article 
essentially states is if a person is unable to communicate without the use 
of profane language their is something wrong with them, and it is common 
that a patient using profane language is trying to take control over a 
situation by force rather than by more gentle forms of persuasion. 
(Supporting evidence for the 2nd half of this argument I think is 
frequently found in YouTube comments.)

+amanda2324 "Those who cannot control their tongue are much more likely to 
participate in violent and aggressive activities."

Cite your sources.  Seriously, I would love to see whatever statistical 
study was done on the subject of people who can "control their tongue" and 
the correlation to violent tendencies.

Again, I feel like that's a bit of a generalisation - take military 
personnel, for example; at least, in my experience, even those officers who 
punctuate each sentence with profanity are some of the most physically 
disciplined people I know.
Of course you get the outliers, of aggressive disposition, who'll do 
aggressive things no matter what, but then you could in theory look at any 
aspect of such people and blame it for their actions; if not swearing, what 
next? Their fashion choices? I mean, we already see the stereotypes around 
teenagers wearing hoodies. 

Why do you classify swearing as 'unhealthy' though?
I do agree with you on the aspect of reducing stress (staying calm) and 
controlling yourself, and there are certainly applications in which it 
proves useful to use other techniques.
But, if memory fails me not, I remember that swearing often provides a 
effective conduit for people to release stress; as long as it isn't abusive 
(invective swearing) or aimed at someone, is it harmful?

I think, language being an organic, evolving body, swearing and civility 
gradually merge. I mean, the play Pigmalion in the 18th century caused an 
uproar with the then taboo word "bloody". 

Also, as a final point (to my somewhat lengthy reply) swearing is a 
fantastic way of marking social distance. It can show social distance or 
cohesion, and is, I believe, simply another tool of communication at our 
disposal.

Those who can control their tongue have a much better time controlling 
their physical body.

Those who cannot control their tongue are much more likely to participate 
in violent and aggressive activities.

Why? Because you're teaching yourself to release your emotions in an 
unhealthy way, rather than teaching yourself self-control, self-discipline, 
calmness, and reacting or expressing yourself in an intelligent, civilized 
manner.

Censoring movies is absolutely and utterly useless. I am a filmmaker and 
writer and i know the effect of censoring a movie. If you don't want to 
watch the movie and what is in it, then don't. Censoring is the equivalent 
of not watching the movie, because you are taking away key parts of the 
story and plot points as well as character development by censoring stuff 
you may find "Inappropriate" You are simply not watching the movie if you 
censor it, because the language people use actually says a lot about their 
character actually. If you were to make a movie about a bunch of middle 
school/high school students, and there was ZERO swearing, would it be 
realistic? No. Having them swear at a realistic amount adds to the 
character and makes it more believable. Yes, every word has impact, but you 
need to also understand that swear words in movies are there for very 
specific reasons. Writers pick and choose the language certain characters 
use to add to the character and flesh them out. I guess these censorship 
people don't understand that,, perhaps you should learn how characters are 
written in books, movies and TV shows before you go talking about how you 
need to censor every "Bad word" No? ﻿

+David Ackerman Gratuitous swearing can have it's place. Depends on what 
movie/TV show it is, but there are some circumstances where having 
excessive swear words adds to the film in terms of characters and 
atmosphere. Although i do think this is very limited, usually swear words 
in films should be reduced to sentences that need definite power behind 
them, and a well placed swear word can add to the  scene quite heavily. But 
i don't think you would disagree that if you made a film about kids in

every film doesn't has to be "realistic" everyone just know People from the

+Tim Horton  Of course it's better than nothing. Any opinion is better than 
resignation to "I don't know and I don't care". And I don't think I would 
want my kids to see something like a severed head on television, you're 
absolutely right on that. But I'd rather see this kind of effort put 
towards teaching kids that, unfortunately, there are bad things and bad 
people, but we can overcome that with intelligent thought, reason, and 
compassion. I'd rather tell my kids, "yes there's bad, so be good in the 
face of it all," than "the world is so good and we're surrounded by good 
and good is so good that there can be no bad." Anyway, that's my two cents, 
and it could be the entirely wrong way of looking at it. What do I know. We 
had a good conversation with differing opinions. YouTubers, take note.

+Andrew H  I'll have you know something though: I've seen words do things 
medicine could not. In my personal experience. Mind you, it was the 
context, intention and implication of these loving and affirming words that 
made them so powerful. Call it positive psychology or love or divine 
intervention or what have you, but there's nothing dangerous about 
believing in the power of the things unseen. Not when you have firsthand 
experiential evidence. By the way, I apologize for insulting you by calling 
your thinking small.

+Andrew H Yeah I can definitely see the validity in what you're saying now. 
You're right, this may be kind of an exercise in futility. But I think we 
can agree that impressionable children shouldn't hear or see certain things 
so I would hope this option is better than nothing.

And I would argue that "what" we say is insignificant next to "how" we say 
it. I'd say WE build the culture and shouldn't fear it, but we can try to 
change it how we see fit. If that's what this company wants to do, they 
have every right to do so and I'm glad it's a right being exercised. But I 
think it's a waste to try to excise words and just leave the feelings of 
hate and revulsion, sticking to my previous example. I think of it as 
childishly plugging your ears instead of trying to make the world better. 
And, since I know it will be used, I hope I'm wrong to a degree where this 
will make a positive contribution to the world.

+Andrew H I didn't see your first comment. I think I understand where 
you're coming from. I had to look through your pretentious anger to find 
it, though. You may be better equipped to get your point across without 
that. But yes I agree it's not the word itself, it's the context, 
intention, implication and cultural significance that give a word it's 
power. We must understand that these things are all connected, though. You 
can't isolate one from the others.

+Hongru Wang You caught me. I did, in fact, hire her to say ridiculous

And if your empathy is in words, I recommend you reevaluate it. Life isn't

No no, words can heal. Words just can't heal better than medicine. That was 
dangerous romantic thinking there. And words can hurt, that isn't being 
debated. But the words themselves don't hurt. I can look at a close friend 
of mine and shout "faggot" at him and have him not be offended. Why? 
Because I'm not trying to be mean. These words are just words; the only 
weight they have is from how people try to use them. I can absolutely do 
damage using only innocent words, like "Jesus only loves straight people, 
son. So he will never love you." Not one of those single words was 
offensive, but that does so much more damage to a child than "faggot" ever 
could. "Christ hates fags" and "Christ hates you because of who you are" 
are equivalent statements, and I would argue the latter would be more 
damaging (although I can't say for certain). The bottom line is that words 
aren't mean, people are mean. Or was that thinking too "small"? Did I 
ignore too many cliches to make a good point? What bland argument did you 
want me to regurgitate from your side so that I could qualify for being 
capable of thinking that isn't "small".
